skill.name: Writing Hookify Rules
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hookify rule", "write a hook rule", "configure hookify", "add a hookify rule", or needs guidance on hookify rule syntax and patterns.

security_audit.summary: Official skill from a trusted source. Files were read for inventory only. No security concerns were identified.

content.value_statement: You need reliable Hookify rules but the format is easy to miss. This skill guides you through fields, events, and patterns so rules work correctly.
actual_capabilities: Explain required frontmatter fields for Hookify rule files.
Provide event type guidance for bash, file, stop, prompt, and all.
Suggest regex patterns and escaping tips for common risks.
Show how to structure multi condition rules with fields and operators.
Recommend file naming, locations, and gitignore guidance.
limitations: Does not run or validate rules automatically.
Does not edit your files or create rules without your action.
Does not cover non Hookify systems or other hook engines.
Cannot access external repositories or network resources.

use_cases.title: Block risky shell commands
use_cases.description: Create bash event rules that warn or block dangerous commands like rm -rf or chmod 777.

use_cases.title: Prevent debug code
use_cases.description: Add file event rules to warn when console.log or debugger appears in new code.

use_cases.title: Enforce stop checks
use_cases.description: Use stop event rules to require tests, builds, or reviews before completion.

prompt_templates.title: First Hookify rule
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginner adding a simple bash rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a basic Hookify rule that warns when a bash command contains rm -rf. Include proper frontmatter and a clear warning message.

prompt_templates.title: File edit warning
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a file event rule that warns when new text contains eval( or innerHTML assignments. Use a single regex pattern.

prompt_templates.title: Multi condition rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a file event rule that triggers only when editing .env files and the new text contains API_KEY.

prompt_templates.title: Process checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a stop event rule that always triggers and shows a checklist for tests, build, and documentation.

output_examples.input: Make a Hookify rule to warn on console.log in TypeScript files
output: Rule uses file event with conditions for .ts and .tsx paths
Pattern matches console.log in new text
Message explains the risk and suggests a logging alternative

best_practices: Use descriptive, verb based rule names in kebab case.
Start with narrow patterns and expand only after testing.
Include a short explanation and a safe alternative in messages.
anti_patterns: Using broad patterns like log that match unrelated text.
Hard coding exact paths that miss common variants.
Omitting enabled or event fields in frontmatter.

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude and Codex?
faq.answer: Yes. It provides guidance for Hookify rules used with Claude Code workflows and can be adapted for Codex guidance.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: It does not execute or validate rules and cannot access external repositories or network resources.

faq.question: How do I integrate the rules?
faq.answer: Create a .claude/hookify.{name}.local.md file in your project root and Hookify reads it on the next tool use.

faq.question: Does it store or send my data?
faq.answer: No. It only provides guidance and does not store or transmit your data.

faq.question: My rule does not trigger. What should I check?
faq.answer: Verify event type, enabled is true, pattern matches the correct field, and file name follows the hookify.{name}.local.md format.

faq.question: How does this compare to generic regex help?
faq.answer: It focuses on Hookify rule structure, fields, and events rather than general regex usage alone.
